{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:32:50.640
    | text      = Because we had a year of heat spells, and people were dying on the football field during
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:32:56.539
    | text      = two-a-days, so they canceled the second two-a-day.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:32:59.200
    | text      = And I sure loved that year, because I only had to play two-a-days in the morning and
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:04.920
    | text      = not go back after lunch, and it was exhausting.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:09.640
    | text      = I remember it being 113, 114 degrees.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:11.880
    | text      = You know, three days are illegal now.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:14.440
    | text      = But now they tell me 105, 106 last week is the hottest ever recorded in Texas, in the
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:21.680
    | text      = area of Texas where I live.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:23.119
    | text      = Now that's just not true.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:26.240
    | text      = But that's why they lie to you.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:29.920
    | text      = Alex is a straight up psychopath if he was glad for the heat because he didn't have to
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:33.559
    | text      = do two-a-day practices while it was killing kids all around.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:37.359
    | text      = Or I guess maybe that was the COVID vaccine back then too when Alex was a kid.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:41.759
    | text      = Whoops, Alex kind of revealed that young athletes dying while playing their sport isn't completely
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:46.079
    | text      = unheard of and totally a new thing.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:48.880
    | text      = Well he has a memory.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:49.940
    | text      = He's intimately familiar with counterexamples that ruin his own conspiracy theory, but who
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:54.680
    | text      = cares.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:55.680
    | text      = Alex misunderstood a headline in The Guardian that said that Death Valley was nearing the
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:59.759
    | text      = global heat record, which it set in 1913 at 134 degrees Fahrenheit.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:34:05.839
    | text      = He's further just not grasping what a lot of these articles that are coming up are about.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:34:10.559
    | text      = As it turns out, there are a bunch of people who don't believe that reading from 1913 was
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:34:14.440
    | text      = accurate, largely because other stations nearby registered much lower readings.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:34:19.199
    | text      = UCLA climate scientist Daniel Swain is one of the higher profile folks who's skeptical
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:34:24.280
    | text      = of this, and he considers 130 to be the highest reliable reading from that time, and therefore
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:34:29.679
    | text      = he considers 130 to be the record in Death Valley.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:34:34.079
    | text      = There's a lot of discussion surrounding this as the plausibility of Death Valley recording
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:34:37.800
    | text      = temperatures over 130 in the near future is very real.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:34:41.679
    | text      = It's something that could happen.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:34:43.320
    | text      = And would that be a record based on the skepticism of these other scientists that consider this
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:34:48.119
    | text      = reading not to be reliable?
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:34:50.320
    | text      = Who knows?
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:34:51.320
    | text      = Sure.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:34:52.320
    | text      = Alex says that he remembers the temperatures from when he was 10 and 14.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:34:55.920
    | text      = He was born in 1974, so that would be 1984 and 1988.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:01.880
    | text      = His birthday is in February, so he would have already had his birthday by the summer, so
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:06.000
    | text      = these years would be reliable towards what he's saying.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:09.639
    | text      = The highest temperature recorded in Dallas, because that was when he was living in Dallas,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:13.500
    | text      = in 1984 was 108 on August 19th.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:17.679
    | text      = In 1988, the highest temperature was 106 on August 23rd.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:22.920
    | text      = In 2022, the highest temp recorded was 108 on July 20th, and this year, on July 18th,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:30.159
    | text      = it hit 106.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:31.880
    | text      = In 2018, it got to 112.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:34.880
    | text      = Really looking at maximum and minimum temperatures is a good way to make a headline pop, but
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:39.199
    | text      = it's not really the most reliable way to approach this issue.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:42.440
    | text      = If you look at average temperatures, it shows a little bit more of the picture.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:46.440
    | text      = For instance, in 1984, the average temperature in July was 85.5 degrees, whereas in 2022,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:54.400
    | text      = it was 91.8.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:56.719
    | text      = The average in June was 82.5 in 1984, compared to 2022's reading of 86.1.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:36:04.559
    | text      = Even more stark are the winter numbers.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:36:07.019
    | text      = The average for January 1984 was 39.3 degrees, compared to January 2023 coming in at 52.1.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:36:15.679
    | text      = If you take the whole year into account, the average temperature in 1984 was 65.7 degrees,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:36:22.199
    | text      = and in 2022 came in at 68.3.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:36:25.920
    | text      = There are considerable jumps here.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:36:28.320
    | text      = There are a ton more variables that go into the picture of the climate, but just from
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:36:31.639
    | text      = a temperature standpoint, it's dumb to pretend that Alex's memories of football practices
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:36:35.800
    | text      = from when he was a tween mean anything.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

{{TranscriptBlock

    | text      = but this is just stupid.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:36:43.599
    | text      = This means nothing.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock

    | text      = One of the most documented things and easy-to-find stuff is temperature records from-
}}
